dialogue_total.statement: Hello! It seems like you might be thinking about something. What's on your mind today?
Hey! Yeah, I just had a meeting with my advisor that didn't go great. He's not really a fan of me, and it didn't help that I totally blanked on my professor's name.

statement.reasoning: The client shared a detailed and rich account of their situation, emotions, and challenges. They expressed feelings about their advisor and contextualized their academic struggles and health issues. Empathy and rapport seem established, and the client's goals and concerns are clear, indicating readiness to explore motivation and change.

dialogue_total.statement: That sounds frustrating, especially when you're trying to make a good impression. What do you think it would be like if things were more positive between you and your advisor?

Honestly, it would be such a relief. It feels like I'm always on edge around him, like I'm waiting for him to point out something I messed up. It'd be great if he could just acknowledge the progress I've made instead of focusing on the negatives.

statement.reasoning: The client has expressed a clear desire for a better relationship with their advisor and has shown Change Talk by reflecting on positive changes they’ve made. However, there's no specific change goal or next step articulated, and confidence hasn't been explicitly measured. Further exploration of specific goals and steps toward change is warranted.

dialogue_total.statement: Feeling on edge in those meetings must be tough. Imagine how much more motivating it could be if you felt recognized for your progress. What small changes do you think could help in improving this situation?

Maybe if I came in more prepared with specifics for these meetings it might help, like writing down names and anything else he might ask. It'd also be nice if he showed just a bit of interest in my health and progress, but I can't change him.

statement.reasoning: The client expressed a change goal of being more prepared for meetings and identified specific steps like writing down names. They also recognized they can't change the advisor's behavior. Confidence and motivation for change are evident, and there's a decrease in sustain talk as they focus on practical solutions.

dialogue_total.statement: It seems you've already identified a couple of actionable steps, like coming in more prepared and writing down key details. How do you feel about creating a plan to implement these? For instance, you could prepare a checklist before each meeting. As for your advisor's responses, perhaps we can discuss ways to focus on what you can control, like how you communicate your progress. What are your thoughts on that approach?

client: A checklist sounds like a good idea. I can definitely see how being more organized might ease some of the anxiety. As for focusing on what I can control, it's tough because I want him to see that I'm improving, but I guess I need to just keep doing my best and hope he notices eventually.

statement.reasoning: The client has developed a clear action plan to prepare for meetings and acknowledged focusing on controllable aspects like self-presentation. They agreed on self-monitoring through checklists but expressed lingering concerns about the advisor's perception. Confidence is growing but not fully solidified, indicating more time in Choosing is beneficial to strengthen their plan and confidence.

dialogue_total.statement: Having a checklist could definitely help you feel more prepared and confident, which in turn might ease some of that anxiety. It's understandable to want recognition for your hard work, and focusing on what you can control, like your preparation and how you communicate your achievements, could be empowering. Would you like to set a goal around using this checklist for your next meeting? We can also think about how to track your progress and see if there are any other strategies you might want to try.

Yeah, setting a goal to use a checklist sounds doable and could really help me stay on track. Maybe I can just jot down a few key points and questions before the next meeting. As for tracking progress, that might help me see the improvements even if my advisor doesn't. I'm open to trying new strategies, too, if you've got any suggestions.

statement.reasoning: The client has a clear goal to use a checklist for meetings and recognizes the need to focus on what they can control. They have accepted the therapist's suggestions and are open to tracking progress and trying new strategies. Barriers, such as advisor's perception, have been discussed. Confidence in their ability to change is evident, showing readiness for action.

dialogue_total.statement: Creating a checklist for your next meeting is a great goal. Jotting down key points and questions beforehand can definitely keep you on track and help you feel more at ease. Tracking your progress will not only help you see your improvements, but it might also boost your confidence over time. As you continue to focus on what you can control, keeping a journal or a simple log of your achievements and reflections could be a helpful tool. I'm really impressed with your openness to trying new strategies. Let's aim to review how the checklist and tracking your progress works for you in our next session. Remember, it's about taking small steps and being kind to yourself along the way. You're doing wonderfully, and I'm here to support you.

Thanks, that all sounds pretty helpful. I’ll try out the checklist and maybe start jotting things down after meetings too. I appreciate the support—I’ll definitely let you know how it goes next time we talk.

statement.reasoning: The session addressed the client's concerns by developing actionable steps to improve their situation, such as using a checklist for meetings. A follow-up plan to review these strategies was established, fulfilling termination goals.

concern:
title: my advisor was upset that i couldn't remember the name of the professor who is teaching one of my classes this semester
My advisor kinda hates me. He didn't like how my first year of PhD went; I had to spend a lot of time adjusting to the rigor of my program for which I honestly was not prepared. I also developed epilepsy and took awhile to find the right meds to quell the episodes, etc. In the midst, I got myself on probation due to a C. This prohibited me from sitting in for qualifier. Anyways, I have started to blossom particularly over the summer and now as a second year. Lexapro, lamictal, and my tenacity have been integral.

My professor was even really happy and surprised by how well one of my presentations to our industrial partner went. ANYWAYS, I was doing a routine meeting with him today (we meet maybe thrice a year) and he asked how my classes were going. I told that I honestly was feeling way more adjusted and having a lot of fun. I love my polymers class a lot and the professor there is a close acquaintance of mine.

But my other course, the professor is new and I simply never memorized his name. He is Chinese and his name is honestly hard for me to pronounce. I appreciate his class and ask questions actively because the material is one I engage in. I have no disrespect for him at all!

My advisor asked me about who was teaching the class this semester. I believe that I knew his name, but I was certain that I would mispronounce it. And I did not want to do this as it is disrespectful. Additionally, I have a lot of anxiety going into these meetings given my advisor's pre-eexisting disdain for me.  I just knew that what would come out of my mouth would be stutter or embarrassment. So I just blurted out, hmm I honestly don't remember. Lol. And my professor made this face and said, "Ooh that is not good at all. Six weeks in and you don't know his name. Tsk tsk tsk with his mouth". I just smiled and said, yep I don't remember.

Oh well. 

oh and not a single question regarding how my epilepsy is, if it is still serving as a learning disability for me, etc. he's tenured and rightfully profit focused in our group
